subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Unicode proposal again.
msgSnippet: ... That s the default Unicode position.  The argument has been made (and I am endeavoring to keep an open mind about it) that Shavian/QS is a special case
messageBody:
L.W. Brown scripsit:

> And, if not vastly different, then "reuse" shapes as is normally done
> despite the differences in sound.

That's the default Unicode position. The argument has been made (and
I am endeavoring to keep an open mind about it) that Shavian/QS is a
special case where sound-glyph mapping is more important than usual,
and that unifying Shavian F with Quickscript TH (and vice versa) would
be specially damaging to the particular nature of these scripts.

Unifying sound without shape imposes a risk that the writer will use
the wrong shape; unifying shape without sound imposes a risk that the
reader will infer the wrong sound.

Human readers can handle this, but mechanical readers are not so
forgiving, and Shavian and QS are particularly designed to make mechanical
interpretation easy.

So let's collect facts and then go to interpretations.

> Context or special marks can
> differentiate, and characters described by A & B below can be treated
> the same as non-Latin characters (such as from Portuguese, Swedish or
> German) that are included in "Roman" fonts.

(Technically, all those characters are Latin characters; the ASCII
repertoire is called "Basic Latin" in Unicode-speak.)

--
Ambassador Trentino: I've said enough. I'm a man of few words.
Rufus T. Firefly: I'm a man of one word: scram!
--Duck Soup John Cowan <cowan@...>
